title: Isolation of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes from preserved human tumor tissue specimens for downstream characterization
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Tumor tissue preservation
Timing: up to 72 h
This step describes our approach to preserve tissue specimens including human tumor tissues for up to 72 h before the dissociation step. This method for tissue preservation overcomes the limitation of specimen transportation time and enables wider application of the TIL analysis method.
Tumor tissue preservation.
Gently rinse the fresh specimen with saline to remove blood from tissue and place into a TTPR tube.
Make sure the sample is completely immersed in the TTPR solution, and then close the cap tightly.
Place the TTPR tube with specimen in a styrofoam box filled with crushed ice and store the box at 2°C–8°C for up to 72 h.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1843-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Box preparation for TTPR preservation
(A) TTPR tubes are placed in a styrofoam box filled with ice.
(B) The lid is sealed with plastic tape.
Note: Rinsing step with saline can be skipped unless an obvious blood contamination is seen. If using surgically resected samples instead of biopsy, the tissue samples should be cut into small pieces of biopsy size (approximately 5 mm3 as shown in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]) before placing sample into TTPR for preservation. Up to 100 mg of tumor tissue can be preserved in a TTPR tube (20 mL).
Note: A styrofoam box or the substitute should be filled with as much ice as possible, and the lid should be sealed with plastic tape (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). Size of the box should be large enough to keep ice during the storage time.
Tumor tissue dissociation and isolation
Timing: 60 min

This step describes the approach to dissociate tumor tissue to obtain single-cell suspensions. The expected outcome is to extract a sufficient number of various types of immune cells although other types of cells which comprise the tumor microenvironment including tumor cells, fibroblasts, and epithelial and endothelial cells are also isolated simultaneously. We show data of isolated TILs with this method in comparison with the conventional mechanical dissociation method, which was reported previously (Sugiyama et al., 2013[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]; Saito et al., 2016[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). The cell number and the immune phenotype of cells isolated from multiple types of tumors, various tissue sizes and different preservation time are presented.
Note: All reagents are stored at 4°C or on ice unless otherwise specified. Sample incubations and centrifugation are performed at 4°C or on ice unless otherwise specified.
Tumor tissue dissociation.
Prepare 1× TTDR by adding 5 mL of TTDR reconstitution buffer at 20°C–25°C to each TTDR vial and incubate for 5–10 min at 20°C–25°C. Mix well by pipetting and transfer reconstituted TTDR to a 15 mL conical tube containing additional 5 mL of TTDR reconstitution buffer. Keep it aside at 20°C–25°C while preparing the sample. Do not leave the reconstituted TTDR at 20°C–25°C longer than 30 min prior to use.
Note: Make sure that dried reagent at the bottom of the vial is completely reconstituted.
Centrifuge the TTPR tube containing the tissue at 300 × g for 2 min at 4°C. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Aspirate the supernatant down to approximately 0.3 mL in the tube.
Cut tissue into small pieces (around 0.5–1.0 mm per side) using scissors (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Critical: Excessive cutting with scissors may increase cell death. Cutting time should be usually about 20–40 s and no longer than 90 s when the scissor stroke is about 100 times per 60 s. In the case of hard tissues and/or large tissue size, place tube on ice for about 1 min to cool down and resume cutting.
Place the tube at 20°C–25°C and add 5–10 mL of 1× TTDR at 20°C–25°C into the tube, rinsing the scissors while adding it.
Note: We recommend 5 mL of 1× TTDR for up to 50 mg and 10 mL for up to 100 mg. Insufficient volume of 1× TTDR may cause poor cell recovery.
Close the cap tightly and incubate at 20°C–25°C for 15 min on the nutator. Gently tilt and check every 5 min that the tissue pieces are not stuck to the walls of the tube without touching the solution.
During the incubation, place a 50 mL conical tube with a 40 μm cell strainer directly on ice and add 10 mL cold stop buffer to equilibrate the filter membrane.
Critical: Incubation time with TTDR should not exceed 20 min.
Note: The use of a 40 μm cell strainer is recommended to eliminate cell aggregates and/or tissue debris as much as possible, as the purpose of this protocol is mainly to isolate immune cells for flow cytometry analysis. Please choose a larger pore size strainer if you need to isolate larger cells as well.
After the incubation, place the incubation tube at 20°C–25°C and immediately add 5 mL cold stop buffer to the tube and the cap.
Cell isolation.
Immediately decant the solution in the cap to the tube, and then transfer the solution into the strainer.

Note: Pour the solution into the strainer slowly while avoiding overflowing (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Exercise caution with mucosal samples (e.g., colorectal tissues) since they may be stickier and often disrupt the flow of the solution from the strainer.
Add an additional 10 mL cold stop buffer in the TTDR incubation tube for rinsing and decant the solution into the strainer.
Lightly grind the pieces of tissue on the strainer using the top of the syringe plunger for 20–30 s (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Add an additional 8 mL cold stop buffer in the strainer, rinsing the tip of the plunger.
Centrifuge the tube with the strainer at 400 × g for 2 min at 4°C to drop the remaining solution into the tube.
Remove the strainer and close the cap tightly.
Mix by inverting of the tube 10 times.
Critical: The mixing step is indispensable to achieve optimal cell recovery.
Centrifuge at 400 × g for 12 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant cautiously, leaving approximately 5 mL in the tube. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Resuspend the pellet and transfer to a 15 mL conical tube.
Rinse the original tube with 4–5 mL of Stain Buffer (FBS) and transfer to the 15 mL tube. Repeat this step; total volume is 13–15 mL.
Close the cap tightly and invert the tube at least twice.
Centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant cautiously, leaving approximately 100 μL in the tube.
Resuspend the pellet in a total of 2–5 mL Stain Buffer (FBS), and pipette appropriate volume of the cell suspension for cell count.

Note: We recommend hemolysis of cell counting portion if the suspension looks reddish or pinkish. Up to 5 × 106 viable cells can be stained in a tube in this protocol. Optimization of antibodies and reagents are required for your staining panel.
Centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate the supernatant cautiously, leaving 100 μL in the tube for cell staining. Pipette the cell suspension carefully and transfer the cell suspension to a 5 mL round bottom tube. The volume can be adjusted depending on the assay needs.
Note: Leaving 50–100 μL in the tube is recommended for cell surface staining. Different types of tubes can be used although a 5 mL round bottom tube is recommended here. For isotype control staining, cell suspension has to be divided into two tubes.

Cell staining for flow cytometry analysis
Timing: 2 h 30 min
In this part, we describe the staining protocol for TILs isolated in the previous step. The protocol is optimized for flow cytometry analysis. The panel shown here is an example. You may set your own staining panel according to your study design.

Note: All steps including centrifugation are performed at 4°C or on ice unless otherwise specified. Reagents are kept at 4°C or on ice unless otherwise specified. All incubation steps should be performed at 4°C or on ice and protected from light. We recommend using a steel tube stand for incubation on ice as it can cool faster and keep stable temperature during the incubation (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Staining for dead cell exclusion and blocking.
Prepare FVS780 working solution by adding 28 μL DPBS(-) to a 2 μL FVS780 stock solution (dilute it 1:15).
Note: Discard the remaining FVS780 stock solution once thawed.
Add 3 μL of FVS780 working solution to 100 μL TIL suspension, mix thoroughly by pipetting, and incubate for 10 min, protected from light.
Add 5 μL of human Fc Block to the tube, mix thoroughly by pipetting, and incubate for 10 min, protected from light.
During the incubation, prepare the following mixture for staining cell surface molecules.
Add 10 μL of Brilliant Stain Buffer (BSB) Plus to a 1.5 mL microtube.
Add antibodies one by one in the tube containing BSB Plus. Lightly vortex the tube (∼ 1 s) each time an antibody is added. Spin the tube down when needed.
Vortex lightly and spin tube down after the addition of the last antibody. Keep tube on ice or at 4°C, protected from light.

After Fc block incubation (step 4c), add antibody mixture to the tube and mix thoroughly by pipetting 10 times, and incubate for 30 min, protected from light.
Add 3 mL of Stain Buffer (FBS) to the tube and pipette it several times gently.

Centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate supernatant carefully down to approximately 100 μL in the tube.
Repeat step b and c.
Aspirate supernatant, leaving 100 μL in the tube.
Intracellular staining.
Add 1 mL of 1× Fix/Perm Buffer and mix gently by pipetting several times.
Incubate for 50–60 min, protected from light.
Add 3 mL of 1× Perm/Wash Buffer and mix gently by pipetting several times.
Note: Use cold ddH2O when preparing 1× Perm/Wash Buffer.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate supernatant carefully down to approximately 100 μL in the tube.
Repeat step c and d.
Aspirate supernatant, leaving 100 μL in the tube.
Add anti-human FoxP3 antibody (5 μL) and mix well by pipetting several times.
Incubate for 30 min, protected from light.
Add 3 mL of 1× Perm/Wash Buffer vigorously to mix.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate supernatant carefully down to approximately 100 μL in the tube.
Add 3 mL Stain Buffer (FBS) and mix gently by pipetting several times.
Centrifuge at 800 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Aspirate supernatant carefully, leaving approximately 100 μL in the tube.
Note: Addition and incubation of anti-human FoxP3 antibody (steps 6h–6l) can be skipped for the myeloid panel.
Flow cytometry analysis.
Resuspend cell pellets in an appropriate volume of Stain Buffer (FBS), usually in 0.5 mL, and transfer it into a 5 mL round bottom tube with cell strainer snap cap.
Centrifuge at 400 × g for around 30 s at 4°C to drop the solution in the strainer.
Set the tube on the flow cytometer after pipetting the sample in the tube.
Run the sample and acquire data. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5], 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7], and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Note: Keep stained samples on ice or at 2°C–8°C protected from light until acquisition. Data acquisition should be executed within 2 h of staining step.
